title: Influencers in Politics: How Trump’s 2024 Campaign Leveraged Social Media Power
description: In this episode, we break down how the 2024 U.S. presidential campaigns used influencers and social media in unprecedented ways, especially in Donald Trump's success in reaching younger voters.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'Life is Artificial,' where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we’re diving into the fascinating world of influencers in politics, particularly how the 2024 U.S. presidential race saw campaigns leveraging the power of social media creators to reach audiences in new ways. This shift in strategy was especially notable in Donald Trump’s campaign.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Our main source today is an article from *The Information* titled *How Trump Used Influencers to Win Over Voters.* You can check out the full article on their website, and I’ll include a link in the episode description.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So, let’s talk about how both the Democratic and Republican campaigns turned to influencers this election season. For starters, both campaigns recognized that creators—whether on podcasts, TikTok, or other platforms—hold a unique influence over their audiences. But the approach to using these platforms couldn’t have been more different.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Donald Trump, known for his success with social media back in 2016, took things further this time around. His campaign made strategic appearances on popular podcasts, such as *The Joe Rogan Experience* and shows by the *All-In Podcast* crew and *Logan Paul*. In total, Trump showed up on over 20 different shows, which is quite a bit more than Kamala Harris’s four appearances.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Trump’s outreach included not only podcast listeners but a wider network of social media personalities, particularly those with a more conservative lean. A major factor was the support he received from Elon Musk, now the owner of X—formerly Twitter. Musk, with over 200 million followers, was actively vocal in his support for Trump, especially after a July incident that tried to target Trump’s safety. This endorsement acted as a powerful megaphone, helping Trump reach audiences in a way that few traditional endorsements could.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Harris, on the other hand, took a more traditional approach, relying on endorsements from celebrities like Beyoncé and Lady Gaga. Although these names carry a lot of weight, the impact wasn’t quite the same as Musk’s relentless support. Celebrity endorsement might still resonate, but for younger voters, a major influencer may be more persuasive than traditional stars.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: But here’s what’s really interesting: despite her campaign bringing in over 200 influencers to the Democratic National Convention—a full hundred more than the RNC—it didn’t generate the same engagement as Trump’s appearances. Analysts think this might be because Harris’s campaign focused more on influencer engagement without honing in on her message. Some of her online support felt fleeting, like the summer trend around coconut tree memes and 'brat' summer memes. While these were popular, they didn’t convey much about her policies or platform.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: In contrast, Trump’s appearances and endorsements were strategically aimed at specific groups, like young men, or what some analysts call the 'bro vote.' By aligning himself with influencers who connect with this demographic, Trump flipped the vote among 18-to-29-year-old men, a group that Biden had previously won by a solid margin in 2020.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So, what’s the takeaway here? For one, 2024 has shown us that influencers aren’t just an added bonus in political campaigns—they’re becoming a mainstay, a crucial strategy in reaching new voters and building direct, personalized connections.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Looking ahead, we might see campaigns adopting the playbook from Trump’s 2024 approach, focusing on creators who can build long-form, intimate connections with audiences. Traditional campaigns may need to reconsider how they use social media and influencers if they want to reach and sway younger, more media-savvy voters.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: One thing’s for certain: creators are likely to play an even bigger role in the 2028 election cycle. Whether it’s through podcasts, interactive platforms, or new media formats yet to emerge, the ways politicians communicate with voters are changing quickly.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Thanks for tuning in to this episode of 'Life is Artificial.' Don’t forget to check out *The Information*’s article for a deeper look at this topic—the link’s in the description. I’m looking forward to seeing how this trend evolves, and we’ll be here to cover every step along the way. Until next time, stay curious!
